g.text: Potential routes of Ebola virus transmission and infection between people.
been isolated from bodily fluids including blood, stool, semen, saliva, and
; contact with these fluids from infected individuals creates a high risk of
transmission. These infectious fluids can also be formed into droplets which travel in the air
(range unknown, possibly 1 meter) and potentially infect others. EBOV has been det
dried blood and persists on surfaces, so the possibility of fomite transmission exists.
transmission via small aerosol droplets is unlikely from current
Airborne or aerosol transmission of a virus occurs when small, virus
settling on surfaces, leaving behind infectious droplet nuclei that can travel long distances. The small
droplets that can form these droplet nuclei are of
ten called aerosols, but aerosols are also generally
defined as any small liquid or solid particles that are suspended in air
biological aerosols, two categories have been created: small droplets and large droplets. The size
for the diameter of small droplets and large droplets has been disputed, with some proposing small
droplet and aerosol interchangeably to des
cribe particles that have the potential to form droplet
and we use the phrases airborne and aerosol transmission synonymously to describe transmission via
Currently no data exist for whether EBOV forms droplet nuclei. EBOV particle
, yet it is not known if small droplets containing EBOV form within the human
respiratory tract. However, epidemiological data have led to the understanding that EBOV does not
